title: AccorHotels unfazed by Erawan blast
text:
AccorHotels unfazed by Erawan blast 28 Aug 2015 at 03:47 610 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: BUSINESS | WRITER: CHADAMAS CHINMANEEVONG - + Minor buys hotels in Brazil, Portugal Paris-based AccorHotels SA strongly believes in the Thai tourism outlook for the medium and long term despite losing some business from last week's bombing at the Ratchaprasong intersection. 
It will open 13 new hotels and debut a new brand in Thailand in the next three years. 
Patrick Basset, chief operating officer for East and upper Southeast Asia, said Accor remained optimistic about Thai tourism including Bangkok. 
The industry showed a quick recovery after a series of negative factors in recent years, he said. 
"Thailand is still attractive, reflected in our 13 new management agreements with 3,380 rooms this year," Mr Basset said. 
"The new hotel contracts are similar to the figure in the last four years." 
Among the 13, six are located in Bangkok, three in Pattaya, two on Koh Samui and one each in Chon Buri and Chiang Rai. 
Bangkok will be the first Asean city to host Accor's new hotel brand, Mama Shelter, due to open in 2018. 
Mr Basset sees the tourism industry bouncing back by November and predicts foreign tourist arrivals of 27.5 to 28 million. 
The Tourism Authority of Thailand has not revised its target of 28.8 million foreign visitors. 
However, Accor accepts its Bangkok hotels have been hurt by the bombing and their average occupancy will miss their targets through November. 
The situation should return to normal in December, Mr Basset said. 
In the first half, Accor saw average occupancy of 76.5% for its hotels in Thailand, up from 60% in the same period last year. Revenue per available room increased by 31.6% year-on-year. 
Mr Basset called the performance of its hotels in Bangkok "outstanding", with first-half occupancy of 81%, up from 58% in the same period last year, while Phuket recorded 79%, up from 67%. 
Post-incident, average occupancy of its Bangkok hotels is 50-60%. The Novotel Platinum in the Pratunam area has seen 70 room cancellations since the bombing.
